dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, the Fed just cut interest rates, right? Totally out of left field.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the Fed just cut interest rates, right? Totally out of left field.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserve has raised a key interest rate for the third time this year in response to a strong U.S. economy and signaled that it expects to maintain a pace of gradual rate hikes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, no, actually. Powell just raised them. For the third time this year, in fact.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, no, actually. Powell just raised them. For the third time this year, in fact.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserve has raised a key interest rate for the third time this year in response to a strong U.S. economy...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Raised them? For a 'burgeoning economy'? That sounds like, um, an oxymoron to me. Why would you raise rates if things are so good?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Raised them? For a 'burgeoning economy'? That sounds like, um, an oxymoron to me. Why would you raise rates if things are so good?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's what he said, yeah. But he also hinted they might pause soon. And here's the kicker, they, like, took out that line about monetary policy being 'accommodative'.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's what he said, yeah. But he also hinted they might pause soon. And here's the kicker, they, like, took out that line about monetary policy being 'accommodative'.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserve has raised a key interest rate for the third time this year in response to a strong U.S. economy and signaled that it expects to maintain a pace of gradual rate hikes. The FOMC also removed a sentence from its statement that had said monetary policy remains accommodative...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Took out a line? So what? That doesn't mean anything. Just Fed-speak, right? More hot air.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Took out a line? So what? That doesn't mean anything. Just Fed-speak, right? More hot air.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, actually, Powell pretty much came out and said they're prioritizing strengthening the US dollar now, over, you know, fighting inflation. The 'Super Dollar' idea.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, actually, Powell pretty much came out and said they're prioritizing strengthening the U S dollar now, over, you know, fighting inflation. The 'Super Dollar' idea.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...now Powell is presiding over a central bank that is keeping an eye out for signs that inflation is running too hot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Prioritizing the dollar? Not inflation? I thought that was their whole deal! Price stability. And, uh, wasn't the unemployment rate like, super low already? Like 3.9%?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Prioritizing the dollar? Not inflation? I thought that was their whole deal! Price stability. And, uh, wasn't the unemployment rate like, super low already? Like three point nine percent?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At 3.9%, unemployment is arguably at a rate that in the past has marked full employment, and prices of goods, labor, and assets are rising across the board.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it is. And that's usually considered full employment. But, um, some economists, like Rafael Bostic, are saying the inverted yield curve isn't a huge problem. It's more about overinflated asset values now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it is. And that's usually considered full employment. But, um, some economists, like Rafael Bostic, are saying the inverted yield curve isn't a huge problem. It's more about overinflated asset values now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The inverted yield curve is not that big a problem, says Rafael Bostic, CEO...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, so the yield curve being flat isn't a problem, but assets are 'overinflated'? Those things usually go hand-in-hand with, you know, a recession, historically speaking. This sounds like they're just making it up as they go.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so the yield curve being flat isn't a problem, but assets are 'overinflated'? Those things usually go hand-in-hand with, you know, a recession, historically speaking. This sounds like they're just making it up as they go.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although short-term rates remain below long-term rates, an inverted yield curve in which the opposite is true has historically been highly correlated with subsequent economic downturns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, analysts are split, I guess, on whether a flat curve means recession. But, uh, the Fed is concerned about inflation running too hot now, despite spending a decade trying to prevent deflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, analysts are split, I guess, on whether a flat curve means recession. But, uh, the Fed is concerned about inflation running too hot now, despite spending a decade trying to prevent deflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the past decade, the Fed has fought to keep prices from deflating, but now Powell is presiding over a central bank that is keeping an eye out for signs that inflation is running too hot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so they went from worrying about prices falling to worrying about them rising too fast, like, overnight? And what about this whole trade war thing with China? Doesn't that just complicate everything?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so they went from worrying about prices falling to worrying about them rising too fast, like, overnight? And what about this whole trade war thing with China? Doesn't that just complicate everything?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. The article mentions it could, uh, stifle growth and negatively impact US GDP. It's not just steel and aluminum anymore; it's agricultural products too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. The article mentions it could, uh, stifle growth and negatively impact U S G D P. It's not just steel and aluminum anymore; it's agricultural products too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The trade skirmish between the United States and China on steel, aluminum, ...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so what does this mean for, like, actual money? My money. Are we supposed to just, you know, buy Amazon and Disney stock because they can 'price power' their way through this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so what does this mean for, like, actual money? My money. Are we supposed to just, you know, buy Amazon and Disney stock because they can 'price power' their way through this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, UBS did suggest some S&P 500 stocks with pricing power, yeah, like JPMorgan, Amazon, Disney. The idea is that if a company can raise prices faster than its production costs, it's a good bet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, U B S did suggest some S&P five hundred stocks with pricing power, yeah, like JPMorgan, Amazon, Disney. The idea is that if a company can raise prices faster than its production costs, it's a good bet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among those that make the cut are big banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), as well as retail juggernaut Amazon (AMZN) and entertainment giant Walt Disney (DIS).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But what about wages? Aren't those, like, production costs? If wages hit 4% growth, corporate profits just, uh, tank, don't they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But what about wages? Aren't those, like, production costs? If wages hit four percent growth, corporate profits just, uh, tank, don't they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UBS says that corporate profit cycles have historically turned lower once annual wage growth tops 4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's what UBS's research note showed, yeah. Wage growth is around 2.4% for most companies right now, so we're not quite there yet. But energy and utilities are doing well because they can, um, charge more.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what U B S's research note showed, yeah. Wage growth is around two point four percent for most companies right now, so we're not quite there yet. But energy and utilities are doing well because they can, um, charge more.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wage growth for the S&P 500, excluding energy, is running at 2.4% a year... UBS finds that energy, utilities, and materials enjoy the strongest profit margin tailwinds, thanks to pricing growth of 6% to 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So basically, the Fed's confused, the economy's confused, and we should all just invest in gas and light bills while hoping Amazon keeps getting richer. Got it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So basically, the Fed's confused, the economy's confused, and we should all just invest in gas and light bills while hoping Amazon keeps getting richer. Got it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much, but, uh, keep an eye on those dividends too. Helps beat the 3% inflation we're seeing now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much, but, uh, keep an eye on those dividends too. Helps beat the three percent inflation we're seeing now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just as important as pricing power, is a demonstrated history of dividend growth that keeps shareholders ahead of inflation. That wasnt much of a hurdle in the past decade when inflation was at negligible rates, but now running at 3% per year, inflation should be a on your radar when you decide what to do with your money.
